title: Moments by Integrating the Moment-Generating Function

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We introduce a novel method for obtaining a wide variety of moments of a random variable with a well-defined moment-generating function (MGF). We derive new expressions for fractional moments and fractional absolute moments, both central and non-central moments. The new moment expressions are relatively simple integrals that involve the MGF, but do not require its derivatives. We label the new method CMGF because it uses a complex extension of the MGF and can be used to obtain complex moments. We illustrate the new method with three applications where the MGF is available in closed-form, while the corresponding densities and the derivatives of the MGF are either unavailable or very difficult to obtain.


Keywords: Moments, Fractional Moments, Moment-Generating Function.
JEL Classification: C02, C40, C65

[^0]
[^0]:    *Previously entitled "Fractional Moments by the Moment-Generating Function". Corresponding author: Chen Tong, Email: tongchen@xmu.edu.cn. We are grateful to Christian Berg, George Tauchen, and Steen Thorbjørnsen for helpful comments. Chen Tong acknowledges financial support from the Youth Fund of the National Natural Science Foundation of China (72301227), and the Ministry of Education of China, Humanities and Social Sciences Youth Fund (22YJC790117).

# 1 Introduction 

Moments of random variables, including conditional moments, are central to much of economics, finance, and econometrics. In this paper, we introduce a new method for obtaining moments of random variables with a well-defined moment-generating function (MGF). The proposed method is general, computationally efficient, and can offer solutions to problems where standard methods are inadequate.

It is well known that the $k$-th integer moment of a random variable $X$, with MGF, $M_{X}(s)=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{s X}\right]$, is given by $\mathbb{E}\left[X^{k}\right]=M_{X}^{(k)}(0)$, where $M_{X}^{(k)}(s)$ is the $k$-th derivative of $M_{X}(s)$. Non-integer moments and fractional absolute moments, $\mathbb{E}\left|X^{r}\right|, r \in \mathbb{R}$, have more complicated expressions, typically integrals that involve derivatives of the MGF or derivatives of the characteristic function (CF). ${ }^{1}$ In this paper, we derive novel integral expressions for computing fractional moments, including fractional absolute moments, and fractional central moments. Unlike existing expressions, the new expressions do not involve derivatives (of the MGF or the CF). Thus, the new expressions are particularly useful when derivatives are prohibitively difficult to obtain. This is often the case in dynamic models, where the conditional MGF is defined from recursive non-linear expressions. The new method is labelled CMGF because it relies on a complex extension of the MGF, and provides expressions for complex moments, $\mathbb{E}|X|^{r}, r \in \mathbb{C}$. Although complex moments are not commonly used in econometrics, this generalization can be included with minimal adaptation. ${ }^{2}$ The new expressions can also be used for establishing new identities, such as the expression for the reciprocal Gamma function, which we infer from the absolute moment of a Gaussian random variable.

The new CMGF expressions involve integrals, and while these cannot be evaluated analytically in most cases, they facilitate new ways to compute moments numerically, which are fast and accurate. We demonstrate this with the normal-inverse Gaussian distribution. We also show that the CMGF method offers fast and accurate moments in dynamic models, where we are not aware of good alternative methods. Specifically, we use the CMGF method to compute moments of cumulative returns in the Heston-Nandi GARCH (HNG) model, to compute moments of realized volatilities in the Heterogeneous Autoregressive Gamma (HARG) model, and to compute conditional moments in

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. We present the new moment expressions in Section 2. Theorem 1 has the expression for absolute fractional moments for general random variables, Theorem 2 has the expression for fractional moments of non-negative random variables, and Theorem 3 presents a new expression for integer moments. As an example, we apply CMGF to the normal-inverse Gaussian distribution. Section 3 presents three applications of the new expressions in dynamic models, and Section 4 concludes.

# 2 A New Method for Computing Moments (CMGF) 

We will use the following notation: $\mathbb{N}$ denotes the positive integers and $\mathbb{N}_{0}=\{0\} \cup \mathbb{N}$. We use $\mathcal{N}$ to denote a neighborhood about zero, for which $(-\delta, \delta) \subset \mathcal{N}$ for some $\delta>0$, and the positive part of $\mathcal{N}$ is denoted $\mathcal{N}_{+} \equiv\{s \in \mathcal{N}: s>0\}$. We use $z=s+i t$ and $\zeta=\sigma+i \tau$ to represent complex variables, where $s=\operatorname{Re}(z)$ and $t=\operatorname{Im}(z)$, and similarly for $\zeta$.

To avoid possible confusion, we use $\mathbb{E}\left[X^{k}\right]$ to denotes integer moments, $k \in \mathbb{N}$, whereas general moments (including fractional and complex moments) are represented with $\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right], r \in \mathbb{C}$.

Our results are applicable to any random variable with a well-defined MGF, as characterized in the following assumption.

Assumption 1. $X$ is a real random variable with

$$
M_{X}(s)=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{s X}\right]<\infty, \quad \text { for all } \quad s \in \mathcal{N}
$$

where $\mathcal{N}$ is a neighborhood about zero.
The MGF is typically used as a real function with a real argument, such that both $s$ and $M_{X}(s)$ take values in $\mathbb{R}$. In this paper, we establish our results by means of complex arguments, $z \in \mathbb{C}$, such that $M_{X}(z)$ also takes values in $\mathbb{C}$.

To gain some intuition for the complex extension of the MGF, we observe that

$$
\psi(s, t) \equiv M_{X}(s+i t)=\mathbb{E}\left[e^{(s+i t) X}\right] \in \mathbb{C}
$$

nests both the standard moment-generating function, $\psi(s, 0)=M_{X}(s)$, and the characteristic function, $\psi(0, t)=\varphi_{X}(t) \equiv \mathbb{E}\left[e^{i t X}\right]$, as special cases. The complex valued MGF,

$M_{X}(z)$, is the bilateral Laplace-Stieltjes transform (apart from the sign of $z$ ), and for continuous random variables it is similar to the Laplace transform. ${ }^{3}$

The results are based on the following identities.
Lemma 1. Let $x \in \mathbb{R}$ and $z=s+i t \in \mathbb{C}$, where $s>0$ is an arbitrary positive constant.

$$
|x|^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}+e^{-z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad \operatorname{Re}(r)>-1
$$

for any $x \neq 0$, and this identity also holds for $x=0$ if $\operatorname{Re}(r)>0$. For $x>0$ we have

$$
x^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad \operatorname{Re}(r)>-1
$$

Similarly,

$$
x^{k}=\frac{k!}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}+(-1)^{k} e^{-z x}}{z^{k+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad k \in \mathbb{N}_{0}
$$

for any $x \neq 0$, and this identity also holds for $x=0$ if $k \in \mathbb{N}$.
The case, $x=0$, arises as a special case in Lemma 1, requiring results to include a qualification for distributions with positive mass at zero.

Our first result is the following expression for fractional absolute (possibly complex) moments.

Theorem 1 (Absolute moments). Suppose $X$ satisfies Assumption 1, $\xi \in \mathbb{R}$, and $z=s+i t$ with $s \in \mathcal{N}_{+}$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}|X-\xi|^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-\xi z} M_{X}(z)+e^{\xi z} M_{X}(-z)}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t
$$

for $\operatorname{Re}(r) \geq 0$, and if $\operatorname{Pr}(X=\xi)=0$, then the identity holds for all $\operatorname{Re}(r)>-1$.
If $r$ is real, then (1) is equivalent to

$$
\mathbb{E}|X-\xi|^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{e^{-\xi z} M_{X}(z)+e^{\xi z} M_{X}(-z)}{z^{r+1}}\right] \mathrm{d} t
$$

The result obviously covers regular and central absolute moments by setting $\xi=0$ for regular moments and $\xi=\mathbb{E} X$ for central moments. Note that the expression remains

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ The Laplace transform of the density function, $f_{X}(x)$, is $\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-z x} f_{X}(x) \mathrm{d} x$, and it differs from $M_{X}(z)$ in terms of the domain of integration and the sign of the exponent. Moreover, $M_{X}(z)$ is obviously also applicable to discrete distributions and distributions that are mixtures of continuous and discrete distributions.

invariant to the specific value of $s$, so long as $s \in \mathcal{N}_{+}$. In our experience, the choice of $s$ has no practical impact on moment evaluation. Although analytical integration may often be impractical, (1) offers a novel method to evaluate moments numerically. For real moments, $r \in \mathbb{R}$, it is our experience that it is computationally advantageous to use (2) rather than (1).

Interestingly, Theorem 1 can be used to obtain new identities, by equating (1) with an existing expression for absolute moments. For instance, the absolute moment for standard normal random variable, $X \sim N(0,1)$, is $\mathbb{E}|X|^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(\frac{r+1}{2})}{\sqrt{\pi}} 2^{r / 2}$, for $r>-1$, and equating this with (1) yields the following expression for the reciprocal gamma function

$$
\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(\frac{r}{2}+1\right)}=\frac{2^{r / 2}}{\pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z^{2} / 2}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad r>-1
$$

for $z=s+i t$, where $s>0$ is an arbitrary positive constant. While we can only infer that (3) holds for real $r>-1$, the identity actually holds for any $r \in \mathbb{C}$, see Hansen and Tong (2024).

For non-negative random variables we have the following simpler expression for fractional moments.

Theorem 2 (Moments of non-negative random variables). Let $X$ satisfies Assumption 1 and $\operatorname{Pr}(X \geq \xi)=1$ for some $\xi \in \mathbb{R}$. For any $r \in \mathbb{C}$ with $\operatorname{Re}(r) \geq 0$, we have,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[(X-\xi)^{r}\right]=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-\xi z} M_{X}(z)}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t
$$

where $z=s+i t$ with $s \in \mathcal{N}_{+}$. If $X$ is strictly greater than $\xi$, i.e. $\operatorname{Pr}(X>\xi)=1$, then the identity holds for $\operatorname{Re}(r)>-1$.

If $r$ is real, then (4) is equivalent to

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[(X-\xi)^{r}\right]=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{e^{-\xi z} M_{X}(z)}{z^{r+1}}\right] \mathrm{d} t
$$

As an illustration, we apply (4) to an exponentially distributed random variable. This example serves as an illustration because integer moments, $k \in \mathbb{N}$, are easy to obtain from the derivatives, $M_{X}^{(k)}(s)$, and other moments can be obtained by evaluating $\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{r} \lambda e^{\lambda x} \mathrm{~d} x$ directly.

Example 1. For an exponentially distributed random variable, with parameter $\lambda>0$, $X \sim \operatorname{Exp}(\lambda)$, we have $M_{X}(z)=\frac{\lambda}{\lambda-z}$, with $\mathcal{N}=(-\infty, \lambda)$. So, the integral in (5) is

$\int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{\lambda}{\lambda-z} \frac{1}{z^{r+1}}\right] \mathrm{d} t$. For an integer moment, $k \in \mathbb{N}$, this integral equals

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\lambda^{-k} \frac{1}{\lambda-z}+\lambda^{-k} \frac{1}{z}+\sum_{j=2}^{k+1} \lambda^{-k+j-1} \frac{1}{z^{j}}\right] \mathrm{d} t & =\lambda^{-k} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{1}{\lambda-z}+\frac{1}{z}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\lambda^{-k} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{\lambda-z^{*}}{\left(\lambda-z^{*}\right)(\lambda-z)}+\frac{z^{*}}{z^{*} z}\right] \mathrm{d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

because $\int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[z^{-j}\right] \mathrm{d} t=0$ for $j>1$. Substituting $z=s+i t$ in the last expression gives us

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda^{-k} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{\lambda-s+i t}{(\lambda-s)^{2}-(i t)^{2}}+\frac{s-i t}{s^{2}-(i t)^{2}}\right] \mathrm{d} t & =\lambda^{-k} \int_{0}^{\infty}\left[\frac{\lambda-s}{(\lambda-s)^{2}+t^{2}}+\frac{s}{s^{2}+t^{2}}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\lambda^{-k}\left[\left.\arctan \left(\frac{t}{\lambda-s}\right)+\arctan \left(\frac{t}{s}\right)\right|_{0} ^{\infty}\right]=\pi \lambda^{-k}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus that $\mathbb{E}\left[X^{k}\right]=\lambda^{-k} k$ ! as expected. Deriving non-integer moments, $r \notin \mathbb{N}$, can be derived using contour integrals and the Cauchy Integral Theorem. These are the techniques used extensively to prove the main results in this paper.

For random variables whose support may include negative numbers, we have the following result for integer moments.

Theorem 3. Let $X$ satisfy Assumption 1 and let $\xi \in \mathbb{R}$. For $k \in \mathbb{N}$ we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[(X-\xi)^{k}\right]=\frac{k!}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{e^{-\xi z} M_{X}(z)+(-1)^{k} e^{\xi z} M_{X}(-z)}{z^{k+1}}\right] \mathrm{d} t
$$

where $z=s+i t$ with $s \in \mathcal{N}_{+}$.
Because $k$ is real, we have expressed the integral on the form, $\frac{k!}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}[\cdot] \mathrm{d} t$, which tends to be simpler to evaluate numerically than the equivalent expression using the form, $\frac{k!}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty}[\cdot] \mathrm{d} t$.
Remark. In some situations, Theorems 1, 2, and 3, provide different expressions for the same moments. For instance, (4) and (1) must agree for a non-negative random variable, because $\mathbb{E}|X|^{r}=\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right]$ in this case, and for integer moments, these expressions must also agree with (6). This is indeed the case, because the additional term in (1) and the additional term in (6) are both zero for non-negative variables. This is an implication of Lemma A.2, which establishes that $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{e^{-(s+i t) s}}{(s+i t)^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t=0$ for all $x>0$ and all $s>0$.

We can combine Theorems 1 and 3 to compute odd moments over tail events.

Corollary 1 (Tail Moments). Let $X$ satisfy Assumption 1, $\xi \in \mathbb{R}$, and let $k$ be odd number. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[(X-\xi)^{k} 1_{\{X>\xi\}}\right] & =+\frac{k!}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{e^{-\xi z} M_{X}(z)}{z^{k+1}}\right] \mathrm{d} t \\
\mathbb{E}\left[(X-\xi)^{k} 1_{\{X<\xi\}}\right] & =-\frac{k!}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{e^{-\xi z} M_{X}(z)}{z^{k+1}}\right] \mathrm{d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

where $z=s+$ it for any $s \in \mathcal{N}_{+}$.
We can also compute the cdf, quantiles, and expected shortfall using the new moment expressions. We can obtain the cdf for a continuous random variable, $X$, from the MGF by Gil-Pelaez inversion,

$$
F_{X}(x)=\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{\pi} \int_{0}^{\infty} \operatorname{Re}\left[\frac{M_{X}(i t) e^{-i t x}}{i t}\right] \mathrm{d} t
$$

where we used that $M_{X}(i t)$ is the characteristic function for $X$. Now the $\alpha$-quantile is given by $\xi_{\alpha} \equiv F_{X}^{-1}(\alpha)$, and we can use Corollary 1 (with $k=1$ ) to compute,

$$
\mathrm{ES}_{\alpha}(X)=-\frac{1}{\alpha} \mathbb{E}\left[X 1_{\left\{X<\xi_{\alpha}\right\}}\right]=-\frac{1}{\alpha} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(X-\xi_{\alpha}\right) 1_{\left\{X<\xi_{\alpha}\right\}}\right]-\xi_{\alpha}
$$

which is known as the expected shortfall.

# 2.1 Example: Moments of NIG Distribution 

To illustrate the new method, we use Theorem 1 to compute fractional moments of the normal-inverse Gaussian (NIG) distribution. The CMGF method is significantly faster and more accurate than both simulation-based methods and direct integration using the NIG density.

The NIG distribution was introduced in Barndorff-Nielsen (1978) and has four parameters, $\lambda$ (location), $\delta$ (scale), $\alpha$ (tail heaviness), and $\beta$ (asymmetry). It has density

$$
f(x)=\frac{\alpha \delta}{\pi \sqrt{\delta^{2}+(x-\lambda)^{2}}} K_{1}\left(\alpha \sqrt{\delta^{2}+(x-\lambda)^{2}}\right) e^{\delta \gamma+\beta(x-\lambda)}, \quad x \in \mathbb{R}
$$

where $\gamma=\sqrt{\alpha^{2}-\beta^{2}}$ and $K_{1}(\cdot)$ is the modified Bessel function of the second kind, and the MGF is given by $M_{X}(z)=\exp \left(\lambda z+\delta\left[\gamma-\sqrt{\alpha^{2}-(\beta-z)^{2}}\right]\right)$, for all $z \in \mathbb{C}$. We consider two standardized NIG distribution (zero mean and unit variance), which can be characterized by the two parameters, $(\xi, \chi)$, for $0 \leq|\chi|<\xi<1$, where $\lambda=-\frac{\chi}{\xi} \zeta, \delta=$ $\xi^{2} \sqrt{\xi^{2}-\chi^{2}} \zeta, \alpha=\xi \zeta$, and $\beta=\chi \zeta$, with $\zeta=\sqrt{1-\xi^{2}} /\left(\xi^{2}-\chi^{2}\right)$, see Barndorff-Nielsen

et al. (1985). Specifically we consider $(\xi, \chi)=(1 / 2,-1 / 3)$ and $(\xi, \chi)=(1 / 8,-1 / 16)$, the corresponding densities are shown in the left panel of Figure 1. The corresponding MGFs, $t \mapsto \operatorname{MGF}(s+i t)$ are shown in the right panel for $s=1$ - solid lines for the real part and dashed lines for the complex part.
![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Densities of two standardized NIG distributions (left panel) and the $t \mapsto \operatorname{MGF}(1+$ $i t$ ) (right panel). The two distributions are for $(\xi, \chi)=(1 / 2,-1 / 3)$ (blue lines) and $(\xi, \chi)=$ $(1 / 8,-1 / 16)$ (red lines).

We compute the absolute moments for $-0.85 \leq r \leq 4.2$ for both distributions using Theorem 1 and the moments are shown in the upper panel of Figure 2. The solid black dot is the second (absolute) moment, which is known to be one for these standardized distributions, and the solid blue and red dots represent the fourth (absolute) moment, which are known to equal $3\left(1+4 \chi^{2}\right) /\left(1-\xi^{2}\right)$. The values provided by the CMGF method are very accurate. The first 12 digits of the fourth moments are correct using a simple implementation in Julia.

Additionally, we compute the absolute moments using $N=1,000,000$ independent draws from the two NIG distributions. The simulation based moment is given by $\tilde{\mu}_{N}^{r}=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left|X_{i}\right|^{r}$ and we estimate the $\sigma^{2}(r)=\operatorname{var}\left(\left|X_{j}\right|^{r}\right)$ with 100 million draws. The accuracy of a simulated moment can be computed from its standard error. Assuming an error equal to one standard deviation, then the number of accurate decimal places is given by $-\log _{10}(\sigma(r) / \sqrt{N}) .{ }^{4}$ We have plotted this number for $N=10^{6}$ in the lower left

panel of Figure 2. The simulation-based moments based on $N=1,000,000$ draws from the distribution are far less accurate. At best, the first few decimal places are accurate, and the accuracy deteriorates rapidly as $r$ increases. In the lower right panels we have shown the moments based on the CMGF method for $3.8 \leq r \leq 4.2$ represented by the solid blue line. The $\times$-crosses are simulation-based moment estimates, each based on $N=1,000,000$ random draws.

The CMGF method is not only far more accurate in this example, it is also much faster than the simulation-based approach. This is shown in Table 1 where we report the computation time obtained with a Julia implementation. In this case the density is readily available, and we also compute the moment by evaluating $\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|x|^{r} f(x) \mathrm{d} x$ using the same numerical integration method used to evaluate the integral in Theorem 1. The CMGF method is between 5 and 25 times faster than the standard approach, and the CMGF method is more than 10,000 times faster than averaging (and generating) $N=10^{6}$ independent draws from the NIG distribution. We have also compared the methods using a standard normal distribution, for which the true moment is known to be, $\mathbb{E}|X|^{r}=\frac{\Gamma\left(\frac{r+1}{2}\right)}{\sqrt{\pi}} 2^{r / 2}$, for all $r>-1$. For the Gaussian case the CMGF is also thousands of times faster than simulation methods using 1 million draws and far more

For moments larger than one, integration with the density is about twice as fast as CMGF, after taking advantage of the symmetric density.

A multivariate extension is beyond the scope of this paper. However, some simple cross-moments, such as $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{1} X_{2}\right]$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{1} X_{2}^{2}\right]$, are easy to obtain from univariate results. Let $\left(X_{1}, X_{2}\right)$ have MGF, $M_{X}\left(t_{1}, t_{2}\right)$, such that $M_{X_{1}+X_{2}}(t)=M_{X}(t, t)$, $M_{X_{1}-X_{2}}(t)=M_{X}(t,-t), M_{X_{1}}(t)=M_{X}(t, 0)$, and $M_{X_{2}}(t)=M_{X}(0, t)$, from which we obtain $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{1}+X_{2}\right)^{k}\right], \mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{1}-X_{2}\right)^{k}\right]$, etc. by Theorem 3 , and the two cross moments are given by $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{1} X_{2}\right]=\frac{1}{2}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{1}+X_{2}\right)^{2}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[X_{1}^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[X_{2}^{2}\right]\right)$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{1} X_{2}^{2}\right]=$ $\frac{1}{6}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{1}-X_{2}\right)^{3}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\left(X_{1}+X_{2}\right)^{3}\right]-2 \mathbb{E}\left[X_{1}^{3}\right]\right)$, respectively.

In the next Section, we compute conditional moments in dynamic models with the CMGF methods. The appropriate density is unknown in most of these problems, and this makes the CMGF method particularly useful.

# 3 Applications to Dynamic Models 

We consider three applications that demonstrate the usefulness of the new CMGF expressions. In the first application, we use Theorems 1 and 3 to obtain moments for cumulative returns from a Heston-Nandi GARCH model. The second application uses Theorem 2 to compute fractional moments of realized volatility that follow an Autoregressive Gamma process. The third application also applies Theorem 2 to obtain fractional moments, but in this case for a discrete distribution that has probability mass at zero.

A common feature of these three applications is that the relevant MGF is available in closed form, while the corresponding density and its derivatives are extremely difficult, if not impossible, to obtain. Although simulation-based methods are always an option, they will tend to be much slower than numerical integration of the new analytical expressions. We will also implement simulation-based methods to compare such with the new moment expressions, and compare their relative computational burden.

We use the following notation: $\mathbb{E}_{t}(\cdot)=\mathbb{E}\left(\cdot \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right)$ is the conditional expectation where $\left\{\mathcal{F}_{t}\right\}$ is the natural filtration. We will typically condition on $\mathcal{F}_{T}$, and use $M_{X_{T+H} \mid T}(z) \equiv$ $\mathbb{E}\left[\exp \left(X_{T+H} z\right) \mid \mathcal{F}_{T}\right]$ to denote the conditional MGF for the random variable $X_{T+H} \in$ $\mathcal{F}_{T+H}$.

### 3.1 Moments of Cumulative Returns in a GARCH Model

The Heston-Nandi GARCH (HNG) model by Heston and Nandi (2000) is given by

$$
\begin{aligned}
& r_{t+1}=r_{f}+\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right) h_{t+1}+\sqrt{h_{t+1}} z_{t+1}, \quad \text { with } \quad z_{t} \sim i i d N(0,1) \\
& h_{t+1}=\omega+\beta h_{t}+\alpha\left(z_{t}-\gamma \sqrt{h_{t}}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $r_{f}$ is the risk free rate; $\lambda$ is the equity risk premium; and $h_{t+1}=\operatorname{var}\left(R_{t+1} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t}\right)$ is the conditional variance of daily log-returns $r_{t+1}=\log \left(S_{t+1} / S_{t}\right)$.

Among the many variations of GARCH models, the HNG model stands out as having an analytical MGF for cumulative returns, $R_{T, H}=\sum_{t=T+1}^{T+H} r_{t}$. The underlying reason is that its dynamic structure is carefully crafted for the purpose of yielding closedform option pricing formulae, and option pricing formulae depend on the properties of cumulative returns, $R_{T, H}=\sum_{t=T+1}^{T+H} r_{t}$. The conditional density function for $R_{T, H}$ does not have a known analytical form, but the corresponding MGF is available in closed form ${ }^{5}$ from simple recursive expressions, as stated below.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{5}$ We follow standard terminology and label an expression as "closed form" if it can be expressed

Proposition 1. Let $r_{t}, t=1,2, \ldots$, be given by (7) and define cumulative returns, $R_{T, H}=r_{T+1}+\cdots+r_{t+H}$. Then the conditional MFG has the affine form,

$$
M_{R_{T, H} \mid T}(z)=\exp \left(A(H, z)+B(H, z) h_{T+1}\right)
$$

which is well-defined for $z \in\left\{\zeta \in \mathbb{C}: B(h, \operatorname{Re}(\zeta))<\frac{1}{2 \alpha}\right.$, for all $\left.h=1, \ldots, H\right\}$, where $A(H, z)$ and $B(H, z)$ are given from the recursions,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A(h+1, z)=A(h, z)+z r_{f}+B(h, z) \omega-\frac{1}{2} \log (1-2 B(h, z) \alpha) \\
& B(h+1, z)=z\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+B(h, z)\left(\beta+\alpha \gamma^{2}\right)+\frac{(z-2 \alpha \gamma B(h, z))^{2}}{2(1-2 \alpha B(h, z))}
\end{aligned}
$$

with initial values, $A(1, z)=z r_{f}$ and $B(1, z)=z\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\frac{z^{2}}{2}$.
Obtaining the moments of cumulative return by way of the derivatives of the MGF is nearly impossible, especially for higher moments and for cumulative returns over many periods (large $H$ ). Instead, we can compute the moments by Theorems 1 and 3, where the former also enables us to compute fractional absolute moments.

We will illustrate this with a simulation design that is based on real data. We estimate the HNG model using daily log returns for the S\&P 500 index from January 1, 2000 to December 30, 2021. The data were obtained from WRDS and the maximum likelihood estimates are presented in Table 2 along with their standard errors (in parentheses).

$$

# 3.2 Moments in Autoregressive Gamma Model 

In this application, $X_{t}$ represents the daily realized variance, which is computed from the intraday transaction data. We follow Corsi et al. (2013) and Majewski et al. (2015) and adopt a Heterogeneous Autoregressive Gamma (HARG) model for $X_{t}$. The HARG model is based on the Autoregressive Gamma (ARG) model by Gourieroux and Jasiak (2006), and both employ a non-central Gamma distribution for the conditional density. ${ }^{6}$ What sets the two apart, is that the HARG employs a long-memory structure for the location parameter. The conditional MGF conveniently has an affine form, which is practical for evaluating the integral expressions for the moments.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ The transition density that is implied by the CIR model, see Cox et al. (1985), is a non-central gamma density, and Engle and Gallo (2006) employed the standard Gamma distribution as the conditional distribution in the MEM model.

The HARG model has

$$
X_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1} \sim f\left(x \mid \delta, \eta, \theta_{t}\right)=\exp \left(-\frac{x}{\eta}-\theta_{t}\right)\left(\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{\delta+k-1}}{\eta^{\delta+k} \Gamma(\delta+k)} \frac{\theta_{t}}{k!}\right), \quad x>0
$$

which is the density for a non-central Gamma distribution with shape parameter $\delta>0$, scale parameter $\eta>0$, and location parameter $\theta_{t}>0$. The location parameter is time-varying, and given by

$$
\theta_{t}=\beta_{d} X_{t}^{(d)}+\beta_{w} X_{t}^{(w)}+\beta_{m} X_{t}^{(m)}
$$

where the variables, $X_{t}^{(d)}=X_{t-1}, X_{t}^{(w)}=\frac{1}{4} \sum_{i=2}^{5} X_{t-i}$, and $X_{t}^{(m)}=\frac{1}{17} \sum_{i=6}^{22} X_{t-i}$ represent lagged daily, "weekly", and "monthly" averages. Observe that $\theta_{t}$ is $\mathcal{F}_{t-1^{-}}$ measurable. The HARG model implies a restricted $\operatorname{AR}(22)$ structure,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{t-1}\left[X_{t}\right]=\eta \delta+\eta \theta_{t}=\mu+\sum_{j=1}^{22} \phi_{j} X_{t-j}
$$

where $\mu=\eta \delta, \phi_{1}=\eta \beta_{d}, \phi_{2}=\cdots=\phi_{5}=\frac{\eta}{4} \beta_{w}$, and $\phi_{6}=\cdots=\phi_{22}=\frac{\eta}{17} \beta_{m}$, as in the HAR model by Corsi (2009).

The estimated parameters are reported in Table 3 along with their standard errors, where $\phi_{d}=\eta \beta_{d}=\phi_{1}, \phi_{w}=\eta \beta_{w}=\sum_{j=2}^{5} \phi_{j}$, and $\phi_{m}=\eta \beta_{m}=\sum_{j=6}^{22} \phi_{j}$, such that $\phi_{d}+\phi_{w}+\phi_{m}=\sum_{j=1}^{22} \phi_{j}$ is a measure of persistence.

The conditional MGF is conveniently given by

$$
M_{X_{T+1} \mid T}(z)=\exp \left(\frac{\eta z}{1-\eta z} \theta_{T+1}-\delta \log (1-\eta z)\right), \quad \text { for } \quad \operatorname{Re}(z)<\eta^{-1}
$$

From the estimated model we compute the term structure of conditional moments, $\mathbb{E}_{T}\left[X_{T+H}^{r}\right]$. The first conditional moment, $r=1$, is given directly from (10), and we will apply Theorem 2 to obtain other moments. The realized variance measures the second moment of returns, such that $r=\frac{1}{2}$ corresponds to the conditional volatility (standard deviation of returns). Similarly, $r=\frac{3}{2}$ and $r=2$ measures of the conditional skewness (of the absolute value) and the conditional kurtosis, respectively. The inverse of volatility corresponds to the negative moment, $r=-\frac{1}{2}$. This moment is interesting because it is used for Shape ratio forecasting and asset allocation, where the inverse of covariance matrix is employed. We compute these four moments by Theorem 2. The analytical form of the conditional MGF of $X_{T}$ is given in Proposition 2.

Proposition 2. Suppose $X_{t}$ follows a HARG(p) process. Then the conditional MGF

for $X_{T+H}$, given $\mathcal{F}_{T}$, is given by

$$
M_{X_{T+H} \mid T}(z) \equiv \mathbb{E}_{T}\left(e^{z X_{t+H}}\right)=\exp \left(A(H, z)+\sum_{j=1}^{p} B_{j}(H, z) X_{T+1-j}\right)
$$

where $A(H, z)$ and $B_{j}(H, z)$, are given from the initial values,

$$
A(1, z)=-\delta \log (1-\eta z) \quad \text { and } \quad B_{j}(1, z)=\frac{z}{1-\eta z} \phi_{i}, \quad j=1, \ldots, p
$$

and the recursions,

$$
\begin{aligned}
A(h+1, z) & =A(h, z)-\delta \log \left[1-\eta B_{1}(h, z)\right] \\
B_{j}(h+1, z) & =\frac{B_{1}(h, z)}{1-\eta B_{1}(h, z)} \phi_{j}+1_{\{j<p\}} B_{j+1}(h, z), \quad j=1, \ldots, p
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that $M_{X_{T+H} \mid T}(z)$ is well defined for $z \in\left\{\zeta \in \mathbb{C}: B_{1}(h, \operatorname{Re}(\zeta))<\eta^{-1}\right.$ for all $h \leq$ $H\}$ and that $p=22$ in this model.

# 3.3 Moments in Autoregressive Poisson Model 

The autoregressive Poisson (ARP) model is given by

$$
\operatorname{Pr}\left(Y_{t}=y \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1}\right)=\frac{\lambda_{t}^{y}}{y!} e^{-\lambda_{t}}, \quad y=0,1, \ldots
$$

where the dynamic intensity parameter evolves according to

$$
\lambda_{t+1}=\omega+\beta \lambda_{t}+\alpha Y_{t}, \quad t=1,2, \ldots
$$

such that $\lambda_{t+1} \in \mathcal{F}_{t}$. The average count over the next $H$ periods is denoted,

$$
\bar{Y}_{T, H}=\frac{1}{H} \sum_{h=1}^{H} Y_{T+h}
$$

and we seek the conditional moments of $\bar{Y}_{T, H}$ given $\mathcal{F}_{T}$. This could in principle be computed from the conditional distributions of $\left(Y_{T+1}, \ldots, Y_{T+H}\right)$, which can be inferred from the ARP model. However, there is substantial combinatorial complexity involved with this, and the complexity increases rapidly with $H$. The new method makes it simpler to compute moments, especially if $H$ is large.

Table 4: ARP Model Estimation Results for Count data of CBOE VIX Jumps

![table_3](table_3)

Note: ML estimation results for the ARP model with robust standard errors in parentheses.

For $H=1$, the conditional MGF is

$$
M_{Y_{T+1} \mid T}(z)=\exp \left(\lambda_{T+1}\left(e^{z}-1\right)\right)
$$

More generally, the analytical form of the conditional MGF of $\bar{Y}_{T, H}$ is given in the following Proposition 3.

Proposition 3. Let $Y_{t}$ be given by (12) and (13). Then

$$
M_{\bar{Y}_{T, H} \mid T}(z)=\exp \left(A(H, z)+B(H, z) \lambda_{T+1}\right)
$$

where $A(H, z)$ and $B(H, z)$ are given from

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A(h+1, z)=A(h, z)+\omega B(h, z) \\
& B(h+1, z)=\beta B(h, z)+\left(e^{z / H+\alpha B(h, z)}-1\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

with initial value $A(1, z)=0$, and $B(1, z)=e^{z / H}-1$.
We estimate an ARP model for daily volatility jumps. Let $Y_{t}$ be the number of daily volatility jumps, as defined by intraday jumps in CBOE VIX index. We obtain high-frequency VIX data from Tick-data for the sample period from July 1, 2003 to

# 4 Conclusion 

In this paper, we introduced a novel method for computing moments, including fractional moments, of random variables using their moment-generating function (MGF). A key advantage of our approach is that it avoids the need for MGF derivatives, which can be computationally challenging or unavailable in many models. We provided new integral expressions for fractional moments, fractional absolute moments, and central moments that extend the applicability of moment computation that is grounded in the MGF. The CMGF method leverages a complex extension of the MGF and is flexible enough to handle non-integer and complex moments.

The CMGF method may be valuable in structural models where moments play an important role. Moments and conditional moments are also central to inference methods. For instance, the generalized method of moments (GMM) by Hansen (1982) requires the mapping from parameter to moments to be known. By offering solutions where other analytical methods fall short, the CMGF method can broaden the applicability of GMM to cover some problems that currently require simulated method of moments (SMM), see McFadden (1989) and Duffie and Singleton (1993).

We found the new method to be very fast and highly accurate for computing moments of the normal-inverse Gaussian distribution. Moreover, the CMGF method is especially useful in dynamic models where the MGF is known but derivatives are difficult to obtain, as demonstrated by the three applications in Section 3, where we computed moments of cumulative returns in a Heston-Nandi GARCH model, moments of realized volatilities in a Heterogeneous Autoregressive Gamma model, and moments of number of volatility jumps in an Autoregressive Poisson model.

Future research could explore further extensions of this method to other models with closed-form MGFs. An interesting extension is to apply the CMGF method to multivariate distributions, allowing for the computation of moments in multivariate distributions, including cross-moments that capture dependencies, beyond the simplest cross-moments, $\mathbb{E}\left[X_{1} X_{2}\right]$, discussed in Section 2.

# A Appendix of Proofs 

Some notation: We write $\mathbb{C}^{+}=\{z \in \mathbb{C}: \operatorname{Re}[z]>0\}$ to denote the complex numbers with positive real part.

In the proof of Theorem 1, we will need the following result (the Laplace transformation of $x^{r}$ ).

Lemma A.1. Let $r+1 \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$and $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$. Then

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{r} e^{-z x} \mathrm{~d} x=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{z^{r+1}}
$$

Proof. Consider the case where $z$ is real and positive, i.e. $z=s>0$. From the definition of the gamma function and the substitution, $y \mapsto s x$, we have $\Gamma(r+1)=$ $\int_{0}^{\infty} y^{r} e^{-y} \mathrm{~d} y=\int_{0}^{\infty} s^{r} x^{r} e^{-s x} s \mathrm{~d} x$, which proves the identity for any $z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$. Both sides of (A.1) are holomorphic functions for $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$, and since they agree on $z \in \mathbb{R}^{+}$, it follows by the identity theorem that they agree for all $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}{ }^{9}$ A different, direct proof for all $z \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$, is presented in the Supplementary Material.

Lemma A.2. For $x<0, \operatorname{Re}(z)>0$, and $\operatorname{Re}(r)>-1$ we have

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t=0
$$

For $x=0$, the identity holds for $\operatorname{Re}(r)>0$.
Proof. We first consider the case $x=0$. The result follows directly from,

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z \cdot 0}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t=\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{1}{(s+i t)^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t=\left.\frac{i}{r} \frac{1}{(s+i t)^{r}}\right|_{-\infty} ^{+\infty}
$$

because the last term is zero for $\operatorname{Re}(r)>0$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ We thank Christian Berg for suggesting this simplification of the proof.

Next, for $x<0$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t & =\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{(s+i t) x}}{(s+i t)^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =-\int_{+\infty}^{-\infty} \frac{e^{(s-i \tau) x}}{(s-i \tau)^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} \tau, \quad \tau=-t \\
& =\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{(s-i \tau) x}}{(s-i \tau)^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} \tau \\
& =e^{s x} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-i \tau x}}{(s-i \tau)^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} \tau \\
& =\lim _{R \rightarrow \infty} e^{s x} \int_{-R}^{+R} f(\tau) \mathrm{d} \tau
\end{aligned}
$$

where $f(\tau)=\frac{e^{-i \tau x}}{(s-i \tau)^{r+1}}$. The seemingly odd change of variables, $\tau=-t$, serves two important purposes that we explain below.

We will use a closed contour integral in the complex plane with two part. The first part is the line segment along the real axis, from $-R$ to $R$, and the second part is the semicircular arc, $C_{R}=\left\{R e^{i \theta}, \theta \in[0, \pi]\right\}$. The integral over the line segment, $\int_{-R}^{+R} f(\tau) \mathrm{d} \tau$, is the object of interest, whereas the semicircle defines an auxiliary integral that is used to close the contour, such that we can apply the Cauchy Integral Theorem. The first reason for the change of variable, $\tau=-t$, is to place the pole of $f(\zeta)$ outside the closed contour for all $R>0$ (the pole is at $\zeta=-i s$ ), such that $0=\int_{-R}^{R} f(\zeta) \mathrm{d} \zeta+$ $\int_{C_{R}} f(\zeta) \mathrm{d} \zeta$ by the Cauchy Integral Theorem. For the integral along the arc, we have the expression,

$$
\int_{C_{R}} f(\zeta) \mathrm{d} \zeta=\int_{C_{R}} e^{-i \zeta x} g(\zeta) \mathrm{d} \zeta=\int_{C_{R}} e^{i a \zeta} g(\zeta) \mathrm{d} \zeta
$$

where $a=-x>0$ and $g(\zeta)=\frac{1}{(s-i \zeta)^{r+1}}$ is continuous and satisfies $\lim _{|\zeta| \rightarrow \infty} g(\zeta)=0$ for all $r+1 \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$. The second reason for the change of variable is that it enables us to apply Jordan's lemma, which requires $a>0$ in the expression above. By Jordan's lemma we have that $\lim _{R \rightarrow \infty} \int_{C_{R}} e^{-i x \zeta} g(\zeta) \mathrm{d} \zeta=0$, which implies that

$$
\int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} f(\tau) \mathrm{d} \tau=\lim _{R \rightarrow \infty} \int_{-R}^{+R} f(\tau) \mathrm{d} \tau=-\lim _{R \rightarrow \infty} \int_{C_{R}} f(\zeta) \mathrm{d} \zeta=0
$$

This completes the proof.
Proof of Lemma 1. Consider first the case $x \geq 0$. Since $\operatorname{Re}[z]=s>0$, we have the

following identity from Lemma A.1,

$$
\int_{0}^{\infty} x^{r} e^{-z x} \mathrm{~d} x=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{z^{r+1}}, \quad \text { for all } \quad \operatorname{Re}[r]>-1
$$

This is the Laplace transform of $x^{r}$ and the inverse Laplace transform is

$$
x^{r}=\frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_{s-i \infty}^{s+i \infty} \frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{z^{r+1}} e^{z x} \mathrm{~d} z, \quad x>0
$$

provided the integral is well defined. Using $x>0$, we can rewrite the integral as

$$
|x|^{r}=x^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi i} \int_{s-i \infty}^{s+i \infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} z=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t
$$

which is well-defined for all $\operatorname{Re}[r]>-1$ (because $x>0$ ). For $x=0$ the expression is well-defined for all $\operatorname{Re}[r]>0$. This completes the proof of the third expression in Lemma 1. We proceed with

$$
\begin{aligned}
|x|^{r} & =x^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t+\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t \\
& =\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}+e^{-z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad x \geq 0
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second term is zero by Lemma A.2.
For the case $x<0$, we have the following identity directly from (A.2),

$$
|x|^{r}=(-x)^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad x<0
$$

Adding $\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t$ to the right-hand side, which equals zero Lemma A.2, we arrive at

$$
|x|^{r}=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-z x}+e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad \text { for } x<0
$$

Combining (A.3) and (A.4) proves the first expression in Lemma 1.
From (A.2), we also have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x^{k}=\frac{\Gamma(k+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{+z x}}{z^{k+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad x>0 \\
& x^{k}=(-1)^{k} \frac{\Gamma(k+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{+\infty} \frac{e^{-z x}}{z^{k+1}} \mathrm{~d} t, \quad x<0
\end{aligned}
$$

This, and $\Gamma(k+1)=k$ ! for $k \in \mathbb{N}$, proves the second expression in Lemma 1. This completes the proof.

Proof of Theorem 1. The proof is the same as in the proof the Theorem 2 by using the first formula in Lemma 1.

Proof of Theorem 2. We prove the result for discrete and continuous distributions separately. Consider first a non-negative discrete random variable, $X$, with support $\mathcal{X}$. Rewriting $\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right]=\sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}} x^{r} p(x)$ using the third formula in Lemma 1 yields

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right] & =\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}}\left[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t\right] p(x) \\
& =\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \sum_{x \in \mathcal{X}} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} p(x) \mathrm{d} t \\
& =\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{M_{X}(z)}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t
\end{aligned}
$$

for $r+1 \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$if $\operatorname{Pr}(X=0)=0$ and $r \in \mathbb{C}^{+}$if $\operatorname{Pr}(X=0)>0$. For a continuous distribution, the same line of arguments gives us,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right]=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\left[\int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{e^{z x}}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t\right] f(x) \mathrm{d} x=\frac{\Gamma(r+1)}{2 \pi} \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{M_{X}(u)}{z^{r+1}} \mathrm{~d} t
$$

This completes the proof.
Proof of Theorem 3. The proof is the same as in the proof the Theorem 1 by using the second formula in Lemma 1.

# B Result for the Dynamic Models ## B. 1 MGF for ARG model Proof of Proposition 1. First, the dynamic process of $\theta_{t}$ can be rewritten as $$ \theta_{T}=\sum_{j=1}^{p} \beta_{j} X_{T-j}, \quad \beta_{i}= \begin{cases}\beta_{d} & j=1 \\ \beta_{w} / 4 & 2 \leq j \leq 5 \\ \beta_{m} / 17 & 6 \leq j \leq 22\end{cases} $$ where $p=22$. For $T=T+H$, assume that the conditional MGF for $X_{T+H}$ is given by $$ M_{T, H}(z)=\mathbb{E}_{T}\left(e^{z X_{T+H}}\right)=\exp \left(A(H, z)+\sum_{j=1}^{p} B_{j}(H, z) X_{T+1-j}\right) $$ For the case, $H=1$, we can use the MGF (11), $$ \mathbb{E}_{T}\left(e^{z X_{T+1}}\right)=\exp \left(\delta \log \frac{1}{1-\eta z}+\frac{\eta z}{1-\eta z} \theta_{T+1}\right)=\exp \left(A(1, z)+\sum_{j=1}^{p} B_{j}(1, z) X_{T+1-j}\right) $$ for $s<\eta^{-1}$ where $$ A(1, z)=-\delta \log (1-\eta z), \quad B_{j}(1, z)=\frac{\eta z}{1-\eta z} \beta_{j}, \quad j=1, \ldots, p $$ The recursions (from $h$ to $h+1$ ) follow from $$ \begin{aligned} \mathbb{E}_{T}\left(e^{z x_{T+h+1}}\right)= & \mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\mathbb{E}_{T+1}\left(e^{z X_{T+h+1}}\right)\right] \\ = & \mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\exp \left(A(h, z)+\sum_{j=1}^{p} B_{j}(h, z) X_{T+2-j}\right)\right] \\ = & \exp \left(A(h, z)+\sum_{j=2}^{p} B_{j}(h, z) X_{T+2-j}\right) \mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\exp \left(B_{1}(h, z) X_{T+1}\right)\right] \\ = & \exp \left(A(h, z)+\sum_{j=1}^{p-1} B_{j+1}(h, z) X_{T+1-j}\right) \\ & \times \exp \left(-\delta \log \left(1-\eta B_{1}(h, z)\right)+\frac{\eta B_{1}(h, z)}{1-\eta B_{1}(h, z)} \sum_{j=1}^{p} \beta_{j} X_{T+1-j}\right) \\ = & \exp \left(A(h+1, z)+\sum_{j=1}^{p} B_{j}(h+1, z) x_{T+1-j}\right) \end{aligned} $$ where $$ A(h+1, z)=A(h, z)-\delta \log \left(1-\eta B_{1}(h, z)\right) $$ and $$ B_{j}(h+1, z)= \begin{cases}B_{j+1}(h, z)+\frac{\eta B_{1}(h, z)}{1-\eta B_{1}(h, z)} \beta_{j} & 1 \leq j

# Conditional MGF for Autoregressive Poisson 

Proof of Proposition 2. The conditional MGF for a Poisson distributed random variable, $Y_{t}$, with intensity $\lambda_{t}$, is $\mathbb{E}_{t-1}\left(e^{z Y_{t}}\right)=\exp \left(\lambda_{t}\left(e^{z}-1\right)\right)$. So for the ARP process,

$$
Y_{t} \mid \mathcal{F}_{t-1} \sim \operatorname{Poisson}\left(\lambda_{t}\right), \quad \text { with } \quad \lambda_{t}=\omega+\beta \lambda_{t-1}+\alpha n_{t-1}
$$

The average number over the next $H$ periods, is

$$
\bar{Y}_{T, H}=\frac{1}{H} S_{T, H}, \quad \text { where } \quad S_{T, H}=\sum_{h=1}^{H} Y_{T+h}
$$

We will show, by induction, that $M_{S_{T, H}}(z)$ has an affine structure. For $H=1$, we have $S_{T, 1}=Y_{T+1}$, such that $M_{S_{T, 1}}(z)=\mathbb{E}_{t}\left[e^{z Y_{T+1}}\right]=\exp \left[\lambda_{T+1}\left(e^{z}-1\right)\right]$, which can be expressed in the affined form,

$$
M_{S_{T, 1}}(z)=\exp \left(\tilde{A}(1, z)+\tilde{B}(1, z) \lambda_{T+1}\right), \quad \text { with } \tilde{A}(1, z) \equiv 0 \text { and } \tilde{B}(1, z) \equiv e^{z}-1
$$

Next, suppose that $M_{S_{T, h}}(z)=\exp (\tilde{A}(h, z)+\tilde{B}(h, z) \lambda_{T+1})$ and consider

$$
\begin{aligned}
M_{S_{T, h+1}}(z) & =\mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\exp \left(z S_{T, h+1}\right)\right]=\mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\exp \left(z Y_{T+1}+z S_{T+1, h}\right)\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\mathbb{E}_{T+1}\left\{\exp \left(z Y_{T+1}+z S_{T+1, h}\right)\right\}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\exp \left\{z Y_{T+1}+\tilde{A}(h, z)+\tilde{B}(h, z) \lambda_{T+2}\right\}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\exp \left\{z Y_{T+1}+\tilde{A}(h, z)+\tilde{B}(h, z)\left(\omega+\beta \lambda_{T+1}+\alpha Y_{T+1}\right)\right\}\right] \\
& =\exp \left\{\tilde{A}(h, z)+\tilde{B}(h, z)\left(\omega+\beta \lambda_{T+1}\right)\right\} \mathbb{E}_{T}\left[\exp \left\{\left(z+\alpha \tilde{B}(h, z)\right) Y_{T+1}\right)\right\}\right] \\
& =\exp \left\{\tilde{A}(h, z)+\tilde{B}(h, z)\left(\omega+\beta \lambda_{T+1}\right)\right\} \exp \left\{\lambda_{T+1}\left(e^{z+\alpha \tilde{B}(h, z)}-1\right)\right\} \\
& =\exp \left\{\tilde{A}(h, z)+\tilde{B}(h, z)\left(\omega+\beta \lambda_{T+1}\right)+\lambda_{T+1}\left(e^{z+\tilde{B}(h, z) \alpha}-1\right)\right\} \\
& =\exp \{\underbrace{[\tilde{A}(h, z)+\omega \tilde{B}(h, z)]}_{=\tilde{A}(h+1, z)}+\underbrace{[\beta \tilde{B}(h, z)+\left(e^{z+\tilde{B}(h, z) \alpha}-1\right)]}_{\tilde{B}(h+1, z)} \lambda_{T+1}\}
\end{aligned}
$$

This proves that $M_{S_{T, h+1}}(z)$ has an affine structure and, by an induction argument, so does $M_{S_{T, h+2}}(z), \ldots, M_{S_{T, H}}(z)$. Next, $M_{\bar{Y}_{T, H}}(z)=M_{S_{T, H}}(z / H)$. So, if we set $A(h, z) \equiv$ $\tilde{A}(h, z / H)$ and $B(h, z)=B(h, z / H)$, then $M_{\bar{Y}_{T, H}}(z)=\exp [A(H, z)+B(H, z)] \lambda_{T+1}$ has the affine structure, where $A(h+1, z)=A(k, z)+\omega B(k, z)$ and $B(h+1, z)=$ $\beta B(h, z)+\left(e^{z / H+\alpha B(h, z)}-1\right)$, with initial values $A(1, z)=0$ and $B(1, z)=\left(e^{z / H}-1\right)$.

# B. 2 The MGF in Heston-Nandi GARCH Model 

We first have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{t}\left[\exp \left(v_{1} r_{t+1}+v_{2} h_{t+2}\right)\right]= & \exp \left[v_{1} r+v_{2} \omega+\left[v_{1}\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+v_{2}\left(\beta+\alpha \gamma^{2}\right)\right] h_{t+1}\right] \\
& \times \mathbb{E}_{t}\left[v_{2} \alpha z_{t+1}^{2}+\left(v_{1}-2 v_{2} \alpha \gamma\right) \sqrt{h_{t+1}} z_{t+1}\right] \\
= & \exp \left[v_{1} r+v_{2} \omega+\left[v_{1}\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+v_{2}\left(\beta+\alpha \gamma^{2}\right)\right] h_{t+1}\right. \\
& \left.-\frac{1}{2} \log \left(1-2 v_{2} \alpha\right)+\frac{\left(v_{1}-2 v_{2} \alpha \gamma\right)^{2}}{2\left(1-2 v_{2} \alpha\right)} h_{t+1}\right] \\
= & \exp \left[v_{1} r+v_{2} \omega-\frac{1}{2} \log \left(1-2 v_{2} \alpha\right)\right. \\
& \left.+\left(v_{1}\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+v_{2}\left(\beta+\alpha \gamma^{2}\right)+\frac{\left(v_{1}-2 v_{2} \alpha \gamma\right)^{2}}{2\left(1-2 v_{2} \alpha\right)}\right) h_{t+1}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we show by induction that the conditional MGF has the form,

$$
\mathbb{E}_{t}\left(\exp \left(s \sum_{i=1}^{H} r_{t+i}\right)\right)=\exp \left(A(H, s)+B(H, s) h_{t+1}\right)
$$

For $h=1$ we have

$$
\mathbb{E}_{t}\left(\exp \left(s r_{t+1}\right)\right)=\exp \left(s r+\left(s\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\frac{s^{2}}{2}\right) h_{t+1}\right)=\exp \left(A(1, s)+B(1, s) h_{t+1}\right)
$$

such that $A(1, s)=s r$ and $B(1, s)=s\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+\frac{s^{2}}{2}$. Next, suppose that the MGF has an affine structure for $h$, then for $h+1$ we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}_{t}\left(\exp \left(s \sum_{i=1}^{h+1} r_{t+i}\right)\right)= & \mathbb{E}_{t}\left[\mathbb{E}_{t+1}\left(\exp \left(s \sum_{i=1}^{h+1} r_{t+i}\right)\right)\right] \\
= & \mathbb{E}_{t}\left[\exp \left(s R_{t+1}\right) \mathbb{E}_{t+1}\left(\exp \left(s \sum_{i=1}^{h} r_{t+1+i}\right)\right)\right] \\
= & \mathbb{E}_{t}\left[\exp \left(s R_{t+1}+A(h, s)+B(h, s) h_{t+2}\right)\right] \\
= & \exp \left(A(h, s)+s r+B(h, s) \omega-\frac{1}{2} \log (1-2 B(h, s) \alpha)\right) \\
& \times \exp \left(\left(s\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+B(h, s)\left(\beta+\alpha \gamma^{2}\right)+\frac{(s-2 B(h, s) \alpha \gamma)^{2}}{2(1-2 B(h, s) \alpha)}\right) h_{t+1}\right) \\
= & \exp \left(A(h+1, s)+B(h+1, s) h_{t+1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A(h+1, s)=A(h, s)+s r+B(h, s) \omega-\frac{1}{2} \log (1-2 B(h, s) \alpha) \\
& B(h+1, s)=s\left(\lambda-\frac{1}{2}\right)+B(h, s)\left(\beta+\alpha \gamma^{2}\right)+\frac{(s-2 B(h, s) \alpha \gamma)^{2}}{2(1-2 B(h, s) \alpha)}
\end{aligned}
$$

for any sufficiently small $s=\operatorname{Re}(z)>0$, such that $B(h, s)<\frac{1}{2 \alpha}$ for all $h=1, \ldots, H$, to ensure that $\log (1-2 B(h, s) \alpha) \in \mathbb{R}$. This completes the proof.

# Supplement
## An Direct Proof of Lemma A.1.

Proof of Lemma A.1. By the substitution, $y=z x \in \mathbb{C}$, we have

$$
\lim _{K \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{K} x^{r} e^{-z x} \mathrm{~d} x=\frac{1}{z^{r+1}} \int_{0}^{s K+i t K} y^{r} e^{-y} \mathrm{~d} y
$$

The function $f(y) \equiv y^{r} e^{-y}$, has a pole at $y=0$ if $r<0$, and is a multi-valued function when $r$ is a non-integer. We will adopt the principal value by restricting the angle of $y=\lambda e^{i \theta}$ to $\theta \in(-\pi, \pi]$, and construct a closed contour integral that avoids the pole at $y=0$. The contour is illustrated in Figure S.1.
![img-6.jpeg](img-6.jpeg)

Figure S.1: The closed contour for the integral, $\oint y^{r} e^{-y} \mathrm{~d} y$.

The function, $f(y)$, is analytic over the closed contour for $\lambda>0$, (i.e. it does not include any singularity). Therefore, by the Cauchy Integral Theorem, we have

$$
0=\oint f(y) \mathrm{d} y=\int_{A B} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{B C} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{C D} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{D A} f(y) \mathrm{d} y
$$

where the integral we seek is $-\int_{C D} f(y) \mathrm{d} y$ as $\lambda \rightarrow 0$ and $K \rightarrow \infty$.
For the integral over the arc, DA, we have $y=\lambda e^{i \theta}=\lambda(\cos \theta+i \sin \theta)$, and $d y=$

$i \lambda e^{i \theta} d \theta$, such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{D A}\right|=\left|\int_{D A} y^{r} e^{-y} \mathrm{~d} y\right| & =\left|\int_{\pi / 2}^{0} \lambda^{r} e^{i \theta r} e^{-\lambda(\cos \theta+i \sin \theta)} i \lambda e^{i \theta} \mathrm{~d} \theta\right| \\
& \leq\left|\lambda^{r+1}\right| e^{|\lambda|}\left|\int_{\pi / 2}^{0} e^{i \theta r} e^{-i \lambda \sin \theta} i e^{i \theta} \mathrm{~d} \theta\right| \\
& \leq\left|\lambda^{r+1}\right| e^{|\lambda|}\left|\int_{\pi / 2}^{0} \mathrm{~d} \theta\right|=\frac{\pi}{2} \lambda^{\operatorname{Re}(r)+1} e^{|\lambda|} \rightarrow 0, \quad \text { as } \lambda \rightarrow 0 \text { for } \operatorname{Re}(r)>-1
\end{aligned}
$$

For the BC-integral, we have $y=s K+i u K$ and $\mathrm{d} y=i K \mathrm{~d} u$, such that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|I_{B C}\right|=\left|\int_{s K}^{s K+i t K} y^{r} e^{-y} \mathrm{~d} y\right| & =\left|i K \int_{0}^{t}(s K+i u K)^{r} e^{-(s K+i u K)} \mathrm{d} u\right| \\
& =\left|i K^{r+1} e^{-s K} \int_{0}^{t}(s+i u)^{r} e^{-i u K} \mathrm{~d} u\right| \\
& \leq K^{\operatorname{Re}(r)+1} e^{-s K}\left|\int_{0}^{t}\right|(s+i u)^{r}|\mathrm{~d} u| \rightarrow 0, \quad \text { as } K \rightarrow \infty
\end{aligned}
$$

because $e^{-s K}$ decays faster than $K^{r+1}$ increases. So, as $K \rightarrow \infty$ and $\lambda \rightarrow 0$, we have

$$
0=\lim _{K \rightarrow \infty} \lim _{\lambda \rightarrow 0}\left(\int_{A B} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{C D} f(y) \mathrm{d} y\right)=\lim _{K \rightarrow \infty}\left(\int_{0}^{s K} f(y) \mathrm{d} y+\int_{s K+i t K}^{0} f(y) \mathrm{d} y\right)
$$

The integral we seek is therefore given by,

$$
\lim _{K \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{s K+i t K} f(y) \mathrm{d} y=\lim _{K \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^{s K} f(y) \mathrm{d} y=\Gamma(r+1)
$$

This completes the proof.

# NIG Moments 

The shape of the integrands provide some intuition for the advantage of the CMGF method in the evaluation of moments of the NIG distribution with $(\xi, \chi)=\left(\frac{1}{2},-\frac{1}{3}\right)$. The CMGF integrand is non-negligible over a domain that is very similar for all values of $r$ and the range of the integrand is also similar across $r$. In fact, all CMGF integrands have the same maximum value at zero. For the integrand, $|x|^{r} f(x)$, there is far more variation across different moments, $r$, which may explain that this method is slower than the CMGF method.

![img-7.jpeg](img-7.jpeg)

Figure S.2: Integrands for some selected NIG moments.

# Existing Methods for Fractional Moments 

Existing expressions for positive fractional moments include,

$$
\mathbb{E}|X|^{r}=C_{K} \int_{0}^{\infty} u^{-(1+r)}\left[-\operatorname{Re}\left[\varphi_{X}(u)\right]+\sum_{k=0}^{K} \frac{u^{2 k}}{(2 k)!} \varphi_{X}^{(2 k)}(0)\right] \mathrm{d} u
$$

where $K=\left\lfloor\frac{r}{2}\right\rfloor$ and $C_{K}$ is a positive constant, see Kawata (1972, theorem 11.4.4), and

$$
\mathbb{E}|X|^{r}=\frac{\lambda}{\Gamma(1-\lambda)}\left[\cos \left(\frac{\pi r}{2}\right)\right]^{-1} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\varphi_{X}^{(k)}(0)-\varphi_{X}^{(k)}(u)}{u^{1+\lambda}} \mathrm{d} u
$$

where $k=\lfloor r\rfloor$ and $\lambda=r-k$, see Laue (1980).
Closely relate to (S.1) is the following expression for non-negative random variables,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right]=(-1)^{k} \frac{\lambda}{\Gamma(1-\lambda)} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{M_{X}^{(k)}(0)-M_{X}^{(k)}(-u)}{u^{1+\lambda}} \mathrm{d} u, \quad(X \geq 0)
$$

where $k=\lfloor r\rfloor$ and $\lambda=r-k$, see Schürger (2002), and another expression for nonnegative variables is

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right]=\frac{1}{\Gamma(\bar{\lambda})} \int_{0}^{\infty} u^{\bar{\lambda}-1} M_{X}^{(\bar{k})}(-u) \mathrm{d} u, \quad(X \geq 0)
$$

where $\tilde{k}=\lceil r\rceil>0$ and $\tilde{\lambda}=\tilde{k}-r \in[0,1)$, see Cressie and Borkent (1986). For strictly positive variables we have the following expression for negative fractional moments, $r<0$,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[X^{r}\right]=\frac{1}{\Gamma(-r)} \int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{t^{r+1}} M_{X}(-t) d t, \quad(X>0)
$$

see Schürger (2002, theorem 1.1).

# Code for Implementation 

```

# Julia version 1.11.0
using QuadGK, SpecialFunctions

#
# A particular NIG distribution with zero mean and unit variance
ξ = 1/2; χ = -1/3
α = ξ=√(1-ξ^2)/(ξ^2-χ^2); β = χ=√(1-ξ^2)/(ξ^2-χ^2); γ = √((1-ξ^2)/(ξ^2-χ^2)); δ = γ^3/α^2; λ = -δ=β/γ

#
# CMGF (Theorem 1) Compute Real Absolute Moments
function CMGF_NIG(λ,α,β,δ,γ,r)
    g(t) = real((MGF_NIG(λ,α,β,δ,γ,1=im=t) + MGF_NIG(λ,α,β,δ,γ,-1-im=t))/(1=im=t)^(r+1)) # z=1
    integral, err = quadgk(t -> g(t), 0, Inf, rtol=1e-10)
    return gamma(r+1)=integral/m
end

# Fourth Moment
r = 4
print("True 4th moment $(3+3=(1+4 * \beta^2 / \alpha^2)/(5 * \gamma)) \backslash n "\}
print("CMGF method $(CMGF_NIG(λ, α, β, δ, γ, r)) \backslash n")
True 4th moment 5.777777777777777
CMGF method 5.777777777777793
```

abstract:
We introduce a novel method for obtaining a wide variety of moments of a
random variable with a well-defined moment-generating function (MGF). We derive
new expressions for fractional moments and fractional absolute moments, both
central and non-central moments. The new moment expressions are relatively
simple integrals that involve the MGF, but do not require its derivatives. We
label the new method CMGF because it uses a complex extension of the MGF and
can be used to obtain complex moments. We illustrate the new method with three
applications where the MGF is available in closed-form, while the corresponding
densities and the derivatives of the MGF are either unavailable or very
difficult to obtain.
